title: Agroclimatic Zones of India (Extracted from Chapter-5, pp.7–16)

zones.name: Western Himalayan region

climate.description: Summer season is mild but the winter season experiences severe cold conditions.
climate.rainfall: Average annual rainfall 75cm-150cm; in Ladakh, less than 30cm
vegetation: Varied with height along the hill slopes

soils: Valleys and duns have thick layers of alluvium (Kashmir, Kullu, Dun)
Hill slopes have thin brown hilly soils
water_resources: Perennial rivers like Ganga, Yamuna, Jhelum, Chenab, Satluj and Beas provide irrigation water to canals
Cheap hydel power for agriculture and industries
economy_activities: High altitude alpine pastures (‘dhoks’ or ‘margs’) used by Gujjars, Bakarwals and Gaddis to rear sheep, goats, cattle
problems: Poor accessibility
Soil erosion
Landslides
Inclement weather
Inadequacy of marketing and storage facilities
Population is generally rural-based and poor

zones.name: Eastern Himalayan Region

climate.description: Rugged topography, thick forest cover and sub-humid climate

notes: Shifting cultivation (Jhum) is practised in nearly 1/3 of the cultivated area and food crops are raised mainly for sustenance
problems: Need marked improvement in infrastructural facilities
Soil degradation
Deforestation
solutions: Improve infrastructural facilities to accelerate development
Arrest soil degradation by controlling deforestation and by terracing in hills
Control shifting cultivation by encouraging permanent settlement and subsistence agriculture

zones.name: Lower Gangetic Plains Region
water_resources: Adequate storage of ground water with high water table
Wells and canals are the main source of irrigation
Problem of water logging and marshy lands in some parts

main: Rice (Aman, Aus and Boro—three successive crops in a year)

problems: Small size of holding
Poverty of the farmers
Water logging and marshy lands (acute in some parts)
solutions: Promote allied agriculture activities (horticulture—banana, mango and citrus fruits), pisciculture, poultry, livestock, forage production and seed supply to supplement farmers’ income
Establish an export processing zone for marine and sea foods equipped with modern facilities of freezing, canning, dehydration, and quality control

zones.name: Middle Gangetic Plains Region

climate.description: Hot and humid summer and mild winter season

soils: Fertile alluvial plain drained by Ganga River and its tributaries
water_resources: Vast potential of ground water and surface runoff in the form of perennial rivers
Irrigation through tube wells, canals and wells
30% of GCA is irrigated and cropping intensity is 142%
problems: Soil erosion
Alkaline and saline formations
Waterlogging
Small size of land holdings and poverty
Zinc deficiency in rice is widespread
solutions: Adopt alternative farming systems
Utilise chaur lands for pisciculture to boost agricultural production
Reclamation of usar lands, wastelands, and fallow lands for agriculture and allied activities (agro-forestry, silviculture, floriculture etc.)

zones.name: Upper Gangetic Plains Region
region: Central and western parts of Uttar Pradesh
water_resources: Canal, tube-well and wells are the main source of irrigation
problems: Fluctuations in the price of sugarcane
Inadequacy of marketing and storage facilities
Excessive irrigation of sugarcane, paddy and wheat resulting into the formation of saline and alkaline soils
solutions: Replace soil exhaustive crops with leguminous crops
Improve low land cultivation through water harvesting structures and alternative farming systems
Utilise chaur lands for pisciculture

zones.name: Trans-Gangetic Plains Region
water_resources: Private tube wells and canals provide principal means of irrigation
economy_activities: Dairying is an important economic activity
problems: Water logging
Salinity
Alkalinity
Soil erosion
Falling water table
solutions: Change in the present rice and wheat rotation (both are soil exhaustive)
Promotion of horticulture
Grow pulses like tur and peas in upland conditions
Cultivation of vegetables in the vicinity of industrial clusters
Development of high quality fodder crops and animal feed by stepping up area under fodder production

zones.name: Eastern Plateau and Hills Region
soils: Occasional patches of laterites and alluviums
Most parts are acidic so application of lime is necessary
water_resources: Deficient due to plateau structure and non-perennial streams

kharif_share: During kharif season, 80% is under rice

problems: Nutrient leached soil
Scarce underground water table
Rugged topography poses obstacles in development of irrigation facilities
Agriculturally one of the backward regions where the farmers are tradition bound
Rural unemployment is a chronic problem
solutions: Soil conservation
Quality seeds
Encouragement to the cultivation of groundnut, soybean and redgram in upland

zones.name: Central Plateau and Hills Region

climate.description: Semi-arid in western part and sub-humid in eastern part

problems: Underground water table is scanty and utilization is constrained by hard rock formations
Agriculture is largely dependent on monsoon
solutions: Adopt a package programme to make agriculture remunerative
Dry farming practices are imperative to get good returns and make agriculture sustainable

zones.name: Western Plateau and Hills Region
problems: Rain shadow region of Western Ghats
Region is deficient in water resources
Only 12.4 per cent area is irrigated
solutions: Popularise water saving devices like sprinklers and drip system to increase water use efficiency
Lower value crops of jowar, bajra and rainfed wheat should give way to high value oilseeds like sunflower, safflower and mustard
Five per cent area under rainfed cotton and jowar could be substituted with fruits like ber, pomegranate, mango and guava

zones.name: Southern Plateau and Hills
problems: Only 50 per cent of area cultivated
81 per cent of dry land farming
Low cropping intensity of 111%
Inadequacies of irrigation facilities have made agriculture highly vulnerable and least sustainable
solutions: Divert some area under coarse cereals to pulses and oilseeds
Encourage horticulture, dairy development and poultry farming

zones.name: East Coast Plains and Hills Region
region: Northern Circar coasts of Andhra Pradesh and Orissa
production_significance: Accounts for 20.33% of rice production of the country
Accounts for 17.05% of groundnut production of the country
problems: Alkalinity of soil
solutions: Discourage monoculture of rice and encourage crop diversification
Increase cropping intensity
Cultivation of spices

zones.name: Western Coastal Plains and Ghats

plantation_spices: Plantation crops and spices raised along hill slopes of Western Ghats

solutions: Encourage high value crops
Prawn culture in brackish water

zones.name: Gujarat Plains and Hills
region: Fertile valleys of Mahi and Sabarmati rivers
soils: Red and yellow soils in Jamnagar area
water_resources: Irrigation through wells and tube wells
solutions: Rain water harvesting
Surface and groundwater management
Dryland farming
Wasteland development

zones.name: Western Dry Region
region: Western Rajasthan west of the Aravallis

climate.description: Hot sandy desert, erratic rainfall, high evaporation, contrasting temperatures, absence of perennial rivers, scanty vegetation

economy_activities: Livestock contributes greatly in desert ecology
problems: Famine and drought are common features
High land-man ratio
Land under pastures is low (4.3%)
Cultivable waste and fallow lands account for nearly 42% of the geographical area
Net irrigated area is only 6.3% of net sown area
solutions: Improved irrigation
Fertilizers
Quality seeds

zones.name: The Islands Region
soils: Andaman and Nicobar: medium to very deep red loamy soils, including marine alluvium-derived soils along the coast
notes: Nearly half of the area is under coconut
Area covered with thick forests and agriculture is at a backward stage
Huge potential for Silviculture and Aquaculture
